The debate about same-sex marriage invokes extremely passionate responses from both sides; those supporting the idea say that homosexuals should be given all the same rights and privileges given to heterosexual couples thus, being a civil rights issue . At the same time many opposed to same-sex marriage argue that marriage is in fact a religious institution that is recognized by the state. By redefining marriage, you would in fact not only be changing something that millions consider sacred, but it would be tantamount to the state establishing a religion, by defining the validly or a religious ceremony. Both arguments have merit, and I propose a third alternative that I believe shows proper respect to the religious institutions as well as providing true equal rights to all as guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution. 
 
 While people on both sides of the same-sex marriage issue have valid points, a new system that defines a legal status of domestic partnership while leaving the term, "Marriage" in the hands of the Church is a realistic solution. My proposal is simple, the state would disband the practice of endorsing or recognizing marriage at all, and the state would offer a simple domestic partnership document that can be completed by ANY group of consenting adults allowing for legal spousal documentation. The Church would have total domain over the concept of marriage and if a couple (or more in a polygamist relationship) wanted to have a religious ceremony the church can do whatever it feels is right in accordance with its spiritual laws. I believe that while this idea is somewhat radical, it is the only possible solution that takes into consideration the valid concerns of both sides of the issue.

I see a world filled with social problems, but it has long been filled with social problems. There was no golden age from which we are falling. 
 
 Some people have always made declension arguments, claiming that morals have collapsed and our society is therefore falling apart. I was just reading a pamphlet from the early 19th century by a Christian reformer named Thomas Branagan who warned that morals had collapsed and society was falling apart. He blamed the failure to provide moral instruction to children for what he insisted was a broader social decline. Conservative Christian leaders in the antebellum period decried women giving anti-slavery speeches to mixed-sex audiences. They claimed that with their "promiscuous speeking," such women were destroying the family and undermining morality. But here we are nearly 180 years later, and we still have families, and society is still intact.
 
 I see the broad social changes that have taken place over the past century as mostly good. Women have more opportunities now than we did 100 years ago. African Americans and other minorities are no longer subject to repressive segregation laws or denial of their right to vote. Economic prosperity and access to higher education are available to a greater percentage of the population than they were 100 years ago. 
 
 As for families, I do not see a decline. I see changes, specifically in the number of divorced parents and in the numbers of women with children working outside the home. Divorce is not a good thing, but religion does not appear to prevent it, as the rate of divorce is reportedly higher among conservative evangelical Christians than among atheists and more mainstream Christians. Blaming divorce on the "secularization" of the society makes little sense, because being Christian does not appear to innoculate couples from getting divorced. Whether women with children working is a good or a bad thing depends, I think, on the circumstances of the families we are considering. Perhaps it would be better for one parent to stay home with children when they are very small, but many parents simply cannot afford to do that. The problem for them is not "morals" or the "secularization" of the society; it's economic. Wages in many jobs are simply too low to support a family, and so both parents are forced to work to make ends meet.

I see no credible evidence that "secularization" has produced moral decline, and indeed, I do not see evidence for moral decline. I think we are no more in moral decline today than we were in the early 19th century or at any other time in our history. 
 
 I see the movement for gay equality as an expression of what is good and moral about our society. It is a moral act to work for the full inclusion of all in the society and to treat everyone as equals. It is the moral position to support legal marriage for all of our families, for the protection of all children, not just the children of heterosexuals. To legalize same-sex marriage is a move to strengthen families, not to weaken them. The moral position is the position in favor of same-sex marriage. By legalizing same-sex marriage, we do not decline. Rather, we continue to improve, by extending justice and fairness to all.
